Kemendes Apresiasi China Bantu Pembangunan Pedesaan
05 Nov 2019, 05:21 by Faidah Umu Sofuroh


Foto: kemendes PDTT

Jakarta - Sekretaris Jenderal Pembangunan Daerah Tertinggal, dan Transmigrasi,AnwarSanusi, mengajak sejumlah negara yang tergabung dalam ASEAN Plus Three (APT) untuk mengadopsi program studi banding kepala desa dan Badan Usaha Milik Desa (BUMDes) ke berbagai negara, seperti yang dilakukan Indonesia saat ini. Menurutnya, APT adalah forum yang tepat untuk menyelaraskan program antarnegara, termasuk China.
Pada forum APT yang diselenggarakan di Myanmar tersebut, Anwar mengapresiasi dukungan China terhadap program studi banding kepala desa dan BUMDes dari Indonesia. Menurutnya, China merupakan salah satu negara yang mendukung upaya-upaya pembangunan pedesaan.
"China mendukung upaya-upaya pembangunan pedesaan dan pengentasan kemiskinan. Forum ini merupakan wadah yang sangat baik untuk menyelaraskan kerja sama antara China dengan negara-negara ASEAN," ujarnya dalam keterangan tertulis, Selasa (5/11/2019).
Anwar mengatakan, Melalui IPRCC, China telah aktif melibatkan negara-negara ASEAN dalam pengentasan kemiskinan. Selanjutnya, terdapat program CARE (China-ASEAN Rural Entrepreneurship) yang merupakan kerja sama ASEAN-China dalam menciptakan wirausaha-wirausaha pedesaan.
"Selain itu juga ada program ADF (ASEAN Development Forum) yang bisa dimanfaatkan. Yang mana ini adalah forum Pembangunan Pedesaan ASEAN, sebagai wadah diskusi isu-isu dan pengembangan kebijakan regional terkait pengembangan perdesaan dan pengentasan kemiskinan," ungkapnya.
APT merupakan hubungan kerja sama ASEAN Plus Three (APT) mulai terbentuk sejak 1997 yang melibatkan tiga negara Asia Timur yakni China, Jepang, dan Korea. Adapun KTT APT ke-1 diselenggarakan pada Desember 1997 di Kuala Lumpur pada saat kawasan Asia sedang dilanda krisis ekonomi.
Selama 10 tahun pertama (1997-2007), kerja sama APT didasarkan kepada Joint Statement on East Asia Cooperation, East Asia Vision Group Report dan Report of the East Asia Study Group. China, Jepang, dan Korea Selatan telah mengaksesi Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia (TAC) masing-masing pada 2003 (China) dan 2004 (Jepang dan Korea Selatan).

The Ministry of Appreciation of China Helps Rural Development
05 Nov 2019, 05:21 by Faidah Umu Sofuroh


Photo: Kemendes PDTT

Jakarta - Secretary General of the Development of Disadvantaged Regions, and Transmigration, Anwar Sanusi, invites a number of countries which are members of the ASEAN Plus Three (APT) to adopt a comparative study program for village heads and Village-Owned Enterprises (BUMDes) to various countries, as Indonesia is currently doing . According to him, APT is the right forum to harmonize programs between countries, including China.
At the APT forum held in Myanmar, Anwar appreciated China's support for the comparative study program of village heads and BUMDes from Indonesia. According to him, China is one country that supports rural development efforts.
"China supports rural development efforts and poverty alleviation. This forum is an excellent forum for harmonizing cooperation between China and ASEAN countries," he said in a written statement on Tuesday (11/05/2019).
Anwar said, through the IPRCC, China has actively involved ASEAN countries in poverty alleviation. Furthermore, there is the CARE (China-ASEAN Rural Entrepreneurship) program which is an ASEAN-China partnership in creating rural entrepreneurs.
"In addition, there is also the ADF (ASEAN Development Forum) program that can be utilized. Which is the ASEAN Rural Development Forum, as a forum for discussion of regional policy issues and development related to rural development and poverty alleviation," he said.
APT is an ASEAN Plus Three (APT) cooperation relationship that began in 1997 involving three East Asian countries namely China, Japan and Korea. The 1st APT Summit was held in December 1997 in Kuala Lumpur when the Asian region was hit by an economic crisis.
During the first 10 years (1997-2007), APT cooperation was based on the Joint Statement on East Asia Cooperation, East Asia Vision Group Report and Report of the East Asia Study Group. China, Japan and South Korea have acceded to the Treaty of Amity and Cooperation in Southeast Asia (TAC) in 2003 (China) and 2004 (Japan and South Korea, respectively).
